title.narrative: OCHA - Contribution for the Evaluation of Country-based Pooled Funds 2019 - PJ/2019/01
OCHA - Contribution for the Evaluation of Country-based Pooled Funds 2019

description.narrative: The evaluation team will produce an evaluation report including an executive summary, as well as a presentation on key findings and recommendations. If necessary, country-specific reports will be added. Country-specific reports provide the advantage of detailed descriptions of evaluation findings, conclusions and recommendations for the selected three to five funds. They can thus be useful to Humanitarian Coordinators, Advisory Boards, fund managers and other stakeholders in these countries. Some of these specific, country-level findings may otherwise get lost if they are not included in the global report. Based on the experience of the 2015 CHF evaluation, the disadvantages include: (a) additional time and money required, both from the evaluation team and those reviewing and commenting on the reports, (b) a large number of recommendations, making it difficult to prioritize and implement many recommendations simultaneously, (c) the possibility of contradictory recommendations in different country reports. Further, in contrast to the 2015 CHF evaluation, CBPFs have now been standardized, in line with the Operational Handbook, rendering fund-specific findings and recommendations less important. OCHA’s preference is for a single evaluation report. An evaluation of the CBPFs will provide an independent assessment of the funds during the period 2015 to 2018, since the inception of CBPFs following the issuance of the specific 2015 policy instruction, with the aim of identifying how CBPFs have performed against their main objectives. It will assess the CBPF mechanism’s strengths, weaknesses, and areas where improvements can make a positive difference to the functioning and impact of CBPFs. The evaluation will assess the past performance of CBPFs and includeconcrete recommendations to make the funds fit for the future. The evaluation will assess how CBPFs have performed against their strategic objectives and principles. The CBPF’s three strategic objectives or outcomes are to: a) Improve effectiveness of the humanitarian response by directing funding towards priority humanitarian needs b) Strengthen the leadership and leverage the coordination role of the Humanitarian Coordinator (HC) c) Mobilize resources and support coordination in support of the Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP)

This concept note serves as a funding proposal from the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) to Belgium. Based on an earlier version of this concept note, draft evaluation terms of reference have been developed, on which the Advisory Group (which includes Belgium) is currently being consulted. This process may therefore result in changes. Six donors have agreed verbally or in writing to share the costs of the evaluation: Belgium, Germany, Netherlands, Sweden, the UK, and the US. As the final budget of the evaluation is not yet known, this proposal is based on an estimated budget of US$ 592,250 (including program support costs of 3%). OCHA proposes for Belgium to fund EUR 50,000.
